column2: CHAPTER I
column3: CHAPTER one

column2: An Antagonist
column3: An Antagonist

column2: He stood in the centre of a little crowd of village boys; his golden head was bare in the blazing sun, but the crop of curls seemed thick enough to protect him from its rays, and he was far too engrossed in his occupation to heed any discomfort from the heat.
column3: He stood in the centre of a little crowd of village boys; his golden head was bare in the blazing sun, but the crop of curls seemed thick enough to protect him from its rays, and he was far too engrossed in his occupation to heed any discomfort from the heat.

column2: A slim delicate little lad, with a finely cut face, and blue eyes that by turns would sparkle with animation, and then settle into a dreamy wistfulness, with a deep far-away look in them.
column3: A slim delicate little lad, with a finely cut face, and blue eyes that by turns would sparkle with animation, and then settle into a dreamy wistfulness, with a deep far away look in them.

column2: They were dancing and flashing with excitement now, and his whole frame was quivering with enthusiasm; with head thrown back, and tongue, hand, and foot all in motion, he seemed to have his audience completely spell-bound, and they listened with open eyes and mouths to his oration.
column3: They were dancing and flashing with excitement now, and his whole frame was quivering with enthusiasm; with head thrown back, and tongue, hand, and foot all in motion, he seemed to have his audience completely spell bound, and they listened with open eyes and mouths to his oration.

column2: With one hand he was fingering a large brass button, which figured conspicuously in the centre of his small waistcoat, and this button was the subject of his theme.
column3: With one hand he was fingering a large brass button, which figured conspicuously in the centre of his small waistcoat, and this button was the subject of his theme.

column2: 'My father he rushed forward--"Come on, men; we'll save the old colours!" And they shouted "Hurrah!" as they made after him.
column3: 'My father he rushed forward-"Come on, men; we'll save the old colours!" And they shouted "Hurrah!" as they made after him.

column2: There were guns going, and shells flying, and swords flashing and hacking away, and the enemy poured on with fiery red faces and gnashing teeth!
column3: There were guns going, and shells flying, and swords flashing and hacking away, and the enemy poured on with fiery red faces and gnashing teeth!

column2: My father drew his sword--and no one could stand against him, no one!
column3: My father drew his sword-and no one could stand against him, no one!

column2: He cut and he slashed, and heads and arms and legs rolled off as quick as lightning, one after the other.
column3: He cut and he slashed, and heads and arms and legs rolled off as quick as lightning, one after the other.

column2: He got up to the colours, and with a shout he plunged his sword right through the enemy's body that had stolen them!
column3: He got up to the colours, and with a shout he plunged his sword right through the enemy's body that had stolen them!

column2: The enemy fell stone dead.
column3: The enemy fell stone dead.

column2: My father seized the colours and looked round.
column3: My father seized the colours and looked round.

column2: He was alone! The other soldiers had been beaten back.
column3: He was alone! The other soldiers had been beaten back.

column2: But was he in a funk?
column3: But was he in a funk?

column2: No; he gave a loud "Hurrah!" picked up his sword, and fought his way back, the enemy hard after him.
column3: No; he gave a loud "Hurrah!" picked up his sword, and fought his way back, the enemy hard after him.

column2: It was a race for life, and he ran backwards the whole way; he wasn't going to turn his back to the enemy.
column3: It was a race for life, and he ran backwards the whole way; he wasn't going to turn his back to the enemy.

column2: He pressed on, shouting "Hurrah!" till he got to his own side again, and then he reached his colonel.
column3: He pressed on, shouting "Hurrah!" till he got to his own side again, and then he reached his colonel.

column2: '"Captain dead, sir I've got the colours!" He saluted as he said it, and then dropped dead himself at the colonel's feet, the blood gushing out of his heart, and over his clothes, and over this button!'
column3: '"Captain dead, sir I've got the colours!" He saluted as he said it, and then dropped dead himself at the colonel's feet, the blood gushing out of his heart, and over his clothes, and over this button!'

column2: The little orator paused as he sank his voice to a tragic whisper, then raising it again, he added triumphantly, 'And thirty bullets and six swords had gone through my father's body!
column3: The little orator paused as he sank his voice to a tragic whisper, then raising it again, he added triumphantly, 'And thirty bullets and six swords had gone through my father's body!

column2: That was something like a soldier!'
column3: That was something like a soldier!'

column2: 'Oh, I say!' murmured a small sceptic from the crowd, 'it was twenty bullets last time; make it fifty, Teddy!'
column3: 'Oh, I say!' murmured a small sceptic from the crowd, 'it was twenty bullets last time; make it fifty, Teddy!'

column2: 'And that's the story of my button,' pursued the boy, ignoring with scorn this last remark.
column3: 'And that's the story of my button,' pursued the boy, ignoring with scorn this last remark.

column2: 'And did your father have only one button to his coat?'
column3: 'And did your father have only one button to his coat?'

column2: The voice was a strange one, and the boys turned round to meet the curious gaze of a sturdy little damsel, who had, unnoticed, joined the group.
column3: The voice was a strange one, and the boys turned round to meet the curious gaze of a sturdy little damsel, who had, unnoticed, joined the group.

column2: She was not dressed as an ordinary village child, but in a little rough serge sailor suit, with a large hat to match, set well back on a quantity of loose dark hair.
column3: She was not dressed as an ordinary village child, but in a little rough serge sailor suit, with a large hat to match, set well back on a quantity of loose dark hair.

column2: A rosy-cheeked square-set little figure she was, and her brown eyes, fringed with long black lashes, looked straight at Teddy with something of defiance and scorn in their glance.
column3: A rosy cheeked square set little figure she was, and her brown eyes, fringed with long black lashes, looked straight at Teddy with something of defiance and scorn in their glance.

column2: Though at first a little taken aback, Teddy rose to the occasion.
column3: Though at first a little taken aback, Teddy rose to the occasion.

column2: 'One button!' he said with emphasis; 'the coat was sent to mother with only one button left on; and if you--' here he turned upon his questioner with a little fierceness--'if you had been through such a bloody battle, and killed so many men, you would have burst and lost _all_ your buttons, and not had one left, like father!'
column3: 'One button!' he said with emphasis; 'the coat was sent to mother with only one button left on; and if you-' here he turned upon his questioner with a little fierceness-'if you had been through such a bloody battle, and killed so many men, you would have burst and lost underscore all underscore your buttons, and not had one left, like father!'

column2: There was a round of applause at this, but the small maiden remained undaunted.
column3: There was a round of applause at this, but the small maiden remained undaunted.

column2: 'Is that a true story you told?' she demanded, with severity in her tone.
column3: 'Is that a true story you told?' she demanded, with severity in her tone.

column2: 'Of course it's true,' was the indignant shout of all.
column3: 'Of course it's true,' was the indignant shout of all.

column2: 'Then I tell you, boy, I don't believe a word of it!' And with set determined lips she turned on her heel and walked away, having sown seeds of anger and resentment in more than one boyish breast.
column3: 'Then I tell you, boy, I don't believe a word of it!' And with set determined lips she turned on her heel and walked away, having sown seeds of anger and resentment in more than one boyish breast.

column2: 'Who is she?' asked Teddy as, tired and exhausted by his recital, he threw himself on the grass to rest.
column3: 'Who is she?' asked Teddy as, tired and exhausted by his recital, he threw himself on the grass to rest.

column2: One of the bigger boys answered him.
column3: One of the bigger boys answered him.

column2: 'I seed her come yesterday in a cab from the town to old Sol at the turnpike--she and her mother, I reckon.
column3: 'I seed her come yesterday in a cab from the town to old Sol at the turnpike-she and her mother, I reckon.

column2: They had two carpet bags and a box and a poll parrot in a cage.
column3: They had two carpet bags and a box and a poll parrot in a cage.

column2: I counted them myself, for I was havin' a ride behind, and the woman she called Sol "Father," so the little 'un must be his grandarter!'
column3: I counted them myself, for I was havin' a ride behind, and the woman she called Sol "Father," so the little 'un must be his grandarter!'

column2: 'P'raps they've come from 'Mericky,' suggested a small urchin, capering round on his hands and feet.
column3: 'P'raps they've come from 'Mericky,' suggested a small urchin, capering round on his hands and feet.

column2: 'Polls allays comes over the sea, you know.'
column3: 'Polls allays comes over the sea, you know.'

column2: [Illustration: TEDDY TELLS THE STORY OF HIS FATHER'S HEROIC DEATH.]
column3: [Illustration: TEDDY TELLS THE STORY OF HIS FATHER'S HEROIC DEATH.]

column2: 'She didn't believe me,' murmured Teddy, chewing a wisp of grass meditatively.
column3: 'She didn't believe me,' murmured Teddy, chewing a wisp of grass meditatively.

column2: 'Gals is no good, never!
column3: 'Gals is no good, never!

column2: If she'd been a boy you would 'a fought her, but I shouldn't care for naught like her, Ted.'
column3: If she'd been a boy you would 'a fought her, but I shouldn't care for naught like her, Ted.'

column2: Teddy turned his face upwards to the speaker.
column3: Teddy turned his face upwards to the speaker.

column2: 'No, I couldn't have fought her, Sam, if she'd been a boy.
column3: 'No, I couldn't have fought her, Sam, if she'd been a boy.

column2: I've promised my mother I won't fight again till she gives me leave.
column3: I've promised my mother I won't fight again till she gives me leave.

column2: You see, I fought four boys in one week last time, and she says she won't have it.
column3: You see, I fought four boys in one week last time, and she says she won't have it.

column2: I don't see if it is right for soldiers to fight, why it isn't right for boys!'
column3: I don't see if it is right for soldiers to fight, why it isn't right for boys!'

column2: 'I don't think there's any fellers left for you to fight with, so you're pretty safe.
column3: 'I don't think there's any fellers left for you to fight with, so you're pretty safe.

column2: Besides, it was only Tom Larken, who set them on to try and get your button from you, and he's gone off to another part of the country now.'
column3: Besides, it was only Tom Larken, who set them on to try and get your button from you, and he's gone off to another part of the country now.'

column2: 'I think, p'raps,' went on Teddy slowly, as he turned over on his back and looked up at the clear blue sky above him, 'that I wasn't quite true about the bullets.
column3: 'I think, p'raps,' went on Teddy slowly, as he turned over on his back and looked up at the clear blue sky above him, 'that I wasn't quite true about the bullets.

column2: I think it was six bullets and three sword cuts.
column3: I think it was six bullets and three sword cuts.

column2: I forget when I tell it how many it was; but she said she didn't believe a word!'
column3: I forget when I tell it how many it was; but she said she didn't believe a word!'

column2: Five o'clock struck by the old church clock close by.
column3: Five o'clock struck by the old church clock close by.

column2: Teddy was upon his feet in an instant, and with a wild whoop and shout he was scudding across the green, his curls flying in the wind, and his little feet hardly seeming to touch the ground.
column3: Teddy was upon his feet in an instant, and with a wild whoop and shout he was scudding across the green, his curls flying in the wind, and his little feet hardly seeming to touch the ground.

column2: There was none in the village so quick-footed as Teddy, and for daring feats and downright pluck he held the foremost place.
column3: There was none in the village so quick footed as Teddy, and for daring feats and downright pluck he held the foremost place.

column2: Perhaps this accounted for his popularity, perhaps it was his marvellous aptitude for telling stories, many of them wild productions from his fertile brain, but certain it was that he was the pet and the darling of the village, and none as yet had resisted his sway.
column3: Perhaps this accounted for his popularity, perhaps it was his marvellous aptitude for telling stories, many of them wild productions from his fertile brain, but certain it was that he was the pet and the darling of the village, and none as yet had resisted his sway.

column2: Over the green, up a shady lane, across two fields, and then, breathless and panting, Teddy paused before an old-fashioned farmhouse.
column3: Over the green, up a shady lane, across two fields, and then, breathless and panting, Teddy paused before an old-fashioned farmhouse.

column2: He passed his hands lightly through his curls, pulled himself up with a jerk, and then quietly and sedately opened a latched door and entered the long low-roofed kitchen.
column3: He passed his hands lightly through his curls, pulled himself up with a jerk, and then quietly and sedately opened a latched door and entered the long low roofed kitchen.

column2: There was something very restful in the scene.
column3: There was something very restful in the scene.

column2: A square substantial table covered with a white cloth, in the centre a large bowl of roses and honeysuckle: home-made bread and golden butter, a glass dish of honey in its comb, a plate of fresh watercress, and a currant loaf completed the simple fare.
column3: A square substantial table covered with a white cloth, in the centre a large bowl of roses and honeysuckle: home-made bread and golden butter, a glass dish of honey in its comb, a plate of fresh watercress, and a currant loaf completed the simple fare.

column2: Presiding at the tea-tray was a stern, forbidding-looking woman of sixty or more, opposite her was seated her son, the master of the farm, a heavy-faced, sleepy-looking man; and at his side, facing the door, sat Teddy's mother.
column3: Presiding at the tea tray was a stern, forbidding looking woman of sixty or more, opposite her was seated her son, the master of the farm, a heavy faced, sleepy looking man; and at his side, facing the door, sat Teddy's mother.

column2: A sweet gentle-faced young woman she was, with the same deep blue eyes as her little son; she bore no resemblance to the elder woman, and looked, as she indeed was, superior to her surroundings.
column3: A sweet gentle faced young woman she was, with the same deep blue eyes as her little son; she bore no resemblance to the elder woman, and looked, as she indeed was, superior to her surroundings.

column2: Two years ago she had come with her child to make her home amongst her husband's people, and though at first her mother-in-law, Mrs. Platt, was inclined to look upon her contemptuously as a poor, delicate, useless creature, time proved to her that for steady, quiet work no one could eclipse her daughter-in-law.
column3: Two years ago she had come with her child to make her home amongst her husband's people, and though at first her mother in law, mrs Platt, was inclined to look upon her contemptuously as a poor, delicate, useless creature, time proved to her that for steady, quiet work no one could eclipse her daughter in law.

column2: Young Mrs. John, as she was called, was now her right hand, and the dairy work of the farm was made over entirely to her.
column3: Young mrs john, as she was called, was now her right hand, and the dairy work of the farm was made over entirely to her.

column2: 'Late again, you young scamp!' was the stern greeting of his grandmother, as Teddy appeared on the scene.
column3: 'Late again, you young scamp!' was the stern greeting of his grandmother, as Teddy appeared on the scene.

column2: The boy looked at her with a twinkle in his eye, put his little hand to his forehead, and gave her a military salute.
column3: The boy looked at her with a twinkle in his eye, put his little hand to his forehead, and gave her a military salute.

column2: 'Sorry,' was all he said as he slipped into the chair that was waiting for him.
column3: 'Sorry,' was all he said as he slipped into the chair that was waiting for him.

column2: 'What have you been doing, sonny?' asked the young mother, whose eyes had brightened at the sight of him.
column3: 'What have you been doing, sonny?' asked the young mother, whose eyes had brightened at the sight of him.

column2: 'Telling father's story,' replied Teddy with alacrity.
column3: 'Telling father's story,' replied Teddy with alacrity.

column2: A shadow came over his mother's face, her lips took a distressed curve, but she said nothing, only occupied herself with attending to the child's wants.
column3: A shadow came over his mother's face, her lips took a distressed curve, but she said nothing, only occupied herself with attending to the child's wants.

column2: 'Your father was never late for his meals,' the grandmother put in with asperity.
column3: 'Your father was never late for his meals,' the grandmother put in with asperity.

column2: 'Never, granny?
column3: 'Never, granny?

column2: Not when he was a boy?
column3: Not when he was a boy?

column2: I shall be always in time when I'm a soldier.'
column3: I shall be always in time when I'm a soldier.'

column2: 'Better begin now, then; bad habits, like weeds, grow apace!'
column3: 'Better begin now, then; bad habits, like weeds, grow apace!'

column2: Teddy had no answer for this; his mouth was full of bread and butter, and he did not speak till the meal was over.

column2: Then, whilst tea was being taken away by the women, he turned to his uncle, who, pulling out a pipe from his pocket, sat down by the open door to smoke.
column3: Then, whilst tea was being taken away by the women, he turned to his uncle, who, pulling out a pipe from his pocket, sat down by the open door to smoke.

column2: 'Uncle Jake!'
column3: 'Uncle Jake!'

column2: A grunt was the only response; but that was sufficient.
column3: A grunt was the only response; but that was sufficient.

column2: The two perfectly understood each other, and a minute after Teddy was perched on his knee.
column3: The two perfectly understood each other, and a minute after Teddy was perched on his knee.

column2: 'I'm wondering if I can't get an enemy!' the boy proceeded, folding his small arms and looking up at his uncle steadily; 'all good people had enemies in the Bible, and I haven't one, I should like to have a good right down enemy!'
column3: 'I'm wondering if I can't get an enemy!' the boy proceeded, folding his small arms and looking up at his uncle steadily; 'all good people had enemies in the Bible, and I haven't one, I should like to have a good right down enemy!'

column2: 'To fight?' asked his uncle.
column3: 'To fight?' asked his uncle.

column2: 'To carry on with, you know; he would lay traps for me, and I would for him, like David and Saul; we should have a fine time of it.
column3: 'To carry on with, you know; he would lay traps for me, and I would for him, like David and Saul; we should have a fine time of it.

column2: And then perhaps, if he did something dreadfully wrong, mother would give me leave to fight him, just once in a way.
column3: And then perhaps, if he did something dreadfully wrong, mother would give me leave to fight him, just once in a way.

column2: Don't you think that would be nice?'
column3: Don't you think that would be nice?'

column2: 'Fightin' ain't the only grand thing in this world; peace is grander,' was the slow response to this appeal.
column3: 'Fightin' ain't the only grand thing in this world; peace is grander,' was the slow response to this appeal.

column2: 'That's what mother says.

column2: She made me learn this morning--"Blessed are the peacemakers!" but you must have an enemy to make peace with, and I haven't got one.'

column2: There was silence; the uncle puffed away at his pipe; he was a good man, and had more brains than his appearance warranted, but Teddy's speeches were often a sore puzzle to him.
column3: There was silence; the uncle puffed away at his pipe; he was a good man, and had more brains than his appearance warranted, but Teddy's speeches were often a sore puzzle to him.

column2: The boy continued in a slow, thoughtful tone, 'I saw some one to-day that I feel might be an enemy, but she's a girl; men don't fight with women.'
column3: The boy continued in a slow, thoughtful tone, 'I saw some one to day that I feel might be an enemy, but she's a girl; men don't fight with women.'

column2: 'I'd rather tackle a man than a woman any day.

column2: They be a powerful enemy sometimes, lad!

column2: And what have this young maid done to you?'
column3: And what have this young maid done to you?'

column2: 'She said,'--and Teddy's eyes grew bright whilst the blood rushed into his cheeks--'she said she didn't believe a word of father's story--not a word of it!
column3: 'She said,'--and Teddy's eyes grew bright whilst the blood rushed into his cheeks-'she said she didn't believe a word of father's story-not a word of it!

column2: And she laughed, and walked away.'
column3: And she laughed, and walked away.'

column2: 'That was coming it strong; and who is she, to talk so?'

column2: 'She's a stranger; Sam said she's come to live with old Sol at the turnpike.'
column3: 'She's a stranger; Sam said she's come to live with old Sol at the turnpike.'

column2: 'That must be Grace's child,' said old Mrs. Platt, coming up and joining in the conversation.
column3: 'That must be Grace's child,' said old mrs Platt, coming up and joining in the conversation.

column2: 'I heard she was coming to stay with her father this summer, and glad I am of it too--the old man is very lonely.

column2: I suppose her husband is at sea again.'
column3: I suppose her husband is at sea again.'

column2: 'What is her husband?' inquired Teddy's mother, as with work in hand she came out and took a seat in the old-fashioned porch.
column3: 'What is her husband?' inquired Teddy's mother, as with work in hand she came out and took a seat in the old-fashioned porch.

column2: 'A sailor.
column3: 'A sailor.

column2: Grace was always a roving nature herself.
column3: Grace was always a roving nature herself.

column2: She never would settle down quiet and take a husband from these parts.
column3: She never would settle down quiet and take a husband from these parts.

column2: She was maid to our squire's lady then, and went to foreign parts with her; but folks say she's steadied down now wonderful.

column2: They've been living at Portsmouth, she and her little girl.'
